034740B38ED1408189E09481C7D5979E.description: Develop new questions for further investigations.

21FE56A6916A481FA5B460300FC6CB3B.description: Compare the trustworthiness of sources of data.

DAAAD89CEDFB46729CC25BC5525E3A34.description: Investigations build on previous knowledge by supporting or contradicting existing knowledge.

03E97BA06AC14031BAEC6FE6FB207900.description: Analysis of data can spark new questions for investigation.

71A1232056444D92B03B1347B4295E49.description: Data can be analyzed by making connections to previous knowledge, comparing for accuracy, asking questions, noticing changes, discussing and collaborating

1537F9BF71284344A388E32EC0F20715.description: Data can be considered accurate when it comes from a trustworthy source, such as textbooks, scientific articles (peer-reviewed journals), official government websites and Elders or Knowledge Keepers

E06850EBF2114CAE815F67C3957D00AC.description: Data can come from many sources, such as investigations, texts, websites, Elders or Knowledge Keepers, community members and personal observations

E2EC5FAB8328454CBD9AD9CD417185DD.description: Objectivity is an attempt to remove the influence of personal thoughts, feelings, and expectations.

2F7246F1355C49C889EEC81FB56BC817.description: Accuracy of data refers to the correctness of a recorded observation.

FF0E4A58345D4428B704D24D484364CC.description: Techniques that can be used to improve the accuracy of data include choosing appropriate tools, carefully measuring, and demonstrating objectivity.

7D4C4FBDE921421A86A041BBA734D48D.description: Students relate investigation to building knowledge.

0F384D4FDA5F41C8879BC5744E6D637B.description: Scientific Methods: Investigation of the physical world is enhanced through the use of scientific methods that attempt to remove human biases and increase objectivity.

E73352CB8A94499DAF0BA3E6C3604A82.description: Identify examples of creativity in computer science, technology, or engineering.

17642F0797F347E19D9975DBA4E92150.description: Create something new by combining, changing, or reapplying existing ideas.

0F8A2A715FF44DC6A80B5692281CA349.description: Relate creativity to engineering, computing, and the development of new technologies.

A70D6D880D9A4790A1512291A8597901.description: Collaborate to write two different sets of instructions that achieve the same outcome.

F46D5F132C7C488BA41FC4E8C056AFF5.description: Identify computational thinking used to solve problems or achieve desired outcomes.

7513F2F15F014CEABB94ECB171146084.description: Create a set of instructions that could be followed by a human or a machine to complete a task.

67ED2F32B79B458A80069A76D3DD4E8A.description: Creativity involves imagination, observation, and making connections.

F9C782D191A84520BE1251E816651C8E.description: Creativity involves divergent thinking and can be used to develop different ways to achieve the same outcome.

55FCA279F0854A7AB2080EA979C5C226.description: Computational thinking is a problem-solving process that uses creativity.

EEC3E8D58F5B46A2938562547E4AEEB5.description: Canadians are responsible for many creative inventions, such as the Canadarm.

DA8DECEF191F4C109A333A929D308631.description: Creativity involves combining, changing, or reapplying existing ideas to produce something new.

E5619721360147BA8ED8D1E8A555338C.description: Creativity is an important part of computer science, technology, and engineering; e.g., computer programming, robotics.

49B122A264644953925926D8F8669090.description: Divergent thinking is the process of generating multiple unique ideas or solutions.

4559D22EFD104C9F8709F8B5473325C9.description: The same outcome, such as arriving at school, can be achieved in different ways.

A81FC52B075A4537886D5E554309CCDE.description: Computational thinking can be used by humans to communicate with computers more efficiently; e.g., apps, virtual reality, and robotics.

196CD9856CB04143AE5E40B2E9EC70D9.description: Computational thinking includes breaking a task into smaller chunks, finding patterns and similarities in tasks, identifying the important details when reading or solving a problem, designing instructions and working backward if a mistake is made

74D9DD6255C2485CA699B6547E51C0DA.description: Students investigate creativity and its relationship to computational thinking.

1268300DFE97409DB81D25E7AB727456.description: Computer Science: Problem solving and scientific inquiry are developed through the knowledgeable application of creativity, design, and computational thinking.

1BBBECEB1E374A7D96772A081B10BAC1.description: Explain interconnections in environments, including how plants depend on animals and how animals depend on plants to survive.

4D4870CA278D4A859DC9C66737DC1FBD.description: Demonstrate respectful and safe practices during observations of plants and animals in local environments.

9873D47A728B4C6EA0593D12A9124B6D.description: Reflect on and share actions that can be taken to protect plants and animals in local environments.

77DFE1F00B8D4C0AAAD8B8DB443D6AF3.description: Investigate and discuss how plants and animals respond to stimuli in their environments in order to survive.

67D9D3F3D35D456C812A5B2F94E27BE8.description: Classify animals in a food chain as carnivores, herbivores, or omnivores.

7232E450BFEB4EF5B354704F7063457A.description: Represent various food chains in local and other Canadian environments.

897073AF01AD4609BDFBAE95ECE51CBE.description: Awareness and consideration of the interactions of plants and animals in local environments helps humans protect them.

313AC18E18814D38A7B46E9C61A8846F.description: Plants and animals sense and respond to stimuli in order to survive.

BE798406D46C4167A90205D17FCB3D17.description: Animals can be classified as carnivores, herbivores, or omnivores based on what they eat.

6A470DF11466415597F2D395DFD6D029.description: Plants and animals interact with each other in various environments in ways that can be represented with food chains.

ED0BC0291ED74338A326F8CD38EAAEB9.description: First Nations, Métis, and Inuit knowledge of plants and animals within environments includes animal behaviour, sources of food, migration patterns and seasonal patterns

EE076C998FD44A148D574E05D9BEF279.description: Plants and animals may depend on each other and their environments for survival, such as for food and habitat.

E5B8E40ED5EA45CC926E8F5DCD19A93A.description: Plants and animals in local environments can be protected by actions such as respectfully interacting with nature, minimizing disturbance to plants and animals, being aware of animal crossings, following fishing and hunting regulations and counting and tracking populations

7B4E91717D584D4E82702B90D4DAA4D3.description: Animals can use senses to detect the presence of food, predators, or other plants and animals.

8335327A9C1D49519F82E91F4603C663.description: Plants and animals use their senses to respond to sensory stimuli, including water, food, temperature and light

8058F86903194B28A4C77BAC8A94EED8.description: Omnivores eat both animals and plants.

B4D498A92EC7460C8ECC103DD47484CF.description: Plants and animals are part of many different food chains.

990ABF5928C649259D50C2BDE7258459.description: A food chain represents one possible way that plants and animals interact.

18E2B3A2ADE34D208CBCDBB3D6FBC43F.description: A food chain can be represented in many ways, such as illustrations, diagrams, stories and words

E2B39A9187854A95B4C3AA065479ACB4.description: A food chain shows the order in which plants and animals depend on each other for food.

D187625DD5AB45E68068F5E4E8600702.description: Students analyze and describe how plants and animals interact with each other and within environments.

D8AC3DFBACC14239A26CA5A9E563FB80.description: Living Systems: Understandings of the living world, Earth, and space are deepened by investigating natural systems and their interactions.

648F7717BBE94E89A5FF2EB80B0CF598.description: Describe how soil is changed by plants and animals.

F8AC57DD42764DABB9463325A50F2A83.description: Identify local habitats provided by soil.

2D3629FC947247C9870114B82A46261F.description: Examine soil and its components in the local community.

8450AE9E9F2C422BB04B3C1FCE80CE72.description: Identify and discuss where fossilized dinosaur bones have been found or are on display in Alberta.

0377DA948C184EF38A6960DF18C8E36F.description: Investigate fossilized dinosaur bones that have been found in Alberta and the dinosaurs they belong to.

10F58C0A24094B79AFC635F7B498646B.description: Explain how paleontologists know that dinosaurs lived on Earth millions of years ago.

8542C866C2C146A18C445F44CA2EB1CB.description: Examine how layers of Earth's surface hold information about the past.

C349C9C8F6AE417ABF3B12F6158741F8.description: Investigate how changing Earth's surface by farming and growing crops contributes to daily life in Alberta.

66DCD5799E554806AC93B5D0A0B7545E.description: Discuss the interconnectedness between human activities and responsibilities for maintaining Earth.

E13AE4E533694F64AA326F4013293026.description: Relate activities of plants and animals to changes in Earth's surface.

80A371CD1509408C980FDD423527F23D.description: Relate human activities to changes in Earth's surface.

350B6CB4C48E4866995D280E98842E9C.description: Investigate glacier-fed rivers that are found locally or in Alberta.

04DE94951F4C4E08939BABDC44C97EAB.description: Represent the flow of water from glaciers to an ocean.

0ACF9886258F4161BC3B3926D0A1647F.description: Represent how the movement of water and wind changes Earth's surface over time.

4F4E77E43B62422884A658E865B1D8E1.description: Investigate natural events that have changed Earth's surface in Alberta.

B133071CEDDA4ED4A298B29D35FC4B99.description: Discuss changes to Earth's surface over time that are shared through stories and intergenerational knowledge of First Nations, Métis, or Inuit.

CC758F2C61AB458790259BA071B4EE46.description: Describe how natural events change Earth's surface.

87117E850C2643209C099D62105F7C19.description: Soil is a continually changing upper layer of Earth's surface.

C9017C2188564D099C838949A6BA8CDC.description: The history of Earth's surface can be explained by examining its layers.

4C87EF95144342BB89BD54BFD1FB7470.description: Plant, human, and other animal activities can cause changes to Earth's surface.

7BECB7A2CEDA4A4590B1C70A9CC1E8DF.description: Water and wind can shape Earth's surface.

4F208D75D2FC43B2B20ADC997B439A6E.description: Relationships with land provide intergenerational knowledge of Earth's surface for many First Nations, Métis, and Inuit.

F65E7688C0BA47B6A81BEE3EF044BCA4.description: Soil can change due to the influence of plants and animals, such as plants and crops growing and worms tunneling and eating matter

4DF56F20288249858C209EC2273957F2.description: Habitats are environments where plants or animals establish a home.

2486907352D24EAE8409A084D9F723DD.description: Soil provides a habitat for many animals.

84B56E552CA24691B6737BCE58DAF2D7.description: Soil includes living plants and animals, decaying plants and animals, rock particles, air and water

3684FB8316404F85B13FC87CB40AD971.description: A scientist who studies fossilized dinosaur bones is called a paleontologist.

3F962512761540848C3D4A0EE74EF73A.description: Displays of fossilized dinosaur bones can be viewed in museums in Alberta such as the Royal Tyrrell Museum in Drumheller and Philip J. Currie Dinosaur Museum in Wembley

255348A7330F4867931DFE3899096EC4.description: Many dinosaurs lived in Alberta, such as Albertosaurus, Edmontosaurus, Nodosaurus and Tyrannosaurus

2CCE119095BC4057B84E7BF731676F2E.description: Dinosaur Provincial Park, located in Alberta's badlands, has been classified as a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

165ADF17616C408999D717D9E50A09B8.description: Fossilized dinosaur bones have been found in several locations in Alberta, such as Alberta's badlands, the Grande Cache area, the Fort McMurray area

73A2149BDF5F4893B412AE769DAB2417.description: Fossilized dinosaur bones can be collected from the surfaces of Earth or by digging up (excavating) its layers.

29913046BB474C1D86310265C7DC93D5.description: Millions of years ago, Earth's surface in Alberta included lush tropical forests and an inland sea that supported dinosaur life and the preservation of dinosaur bones.

95584591840A40ADA833A2E4575ED30B.description: Fossilized dinosaur bones found in many locations around the world show that dinosaurs lived on Earth millions of years ago.

D6D938332072479EBA9C991AC79D1775.description: Earth's surface contains layers that have been deposited over long periods of time.

10BC9EF8F260443AABC615113C8C05FB.description: Plant and animal activities can change Earth's surface, such as overpopulation, using resources, parasite infestation; e.g., mountain pine beetle and animals burrowing

B46D453E1E5F41A9A35669F86D8F9190.description: Human activities that can change Earth's surface include living on the land, building towns and cities, getting and using resources, growing crops and farming (agriculture), polluting and stewardship

184216592306446B938E4F2B73F57B23.description: Interactions with wind and water have shaped Earth's surface, including Alberta's badlands and the Grand Canyon in the United States.

7CF0A7797E6541D8B0E386712483C93B.description: Earth is warming up from natural and human causes, which is accelerating the melting of glaciers.

203325F0A203430482BAD4839935B5A7.description: Melting glacier ice creates runoff that forms and maintains many of the major rivers in Alberta.

89C8C2A75EC34A329ED2478B31713A89.description: Glaciers are the remnants of very thick ice sheets that once covered all of Canada.

F55CA49ABAB54524AE5303479B0A55A3.description: Wind, water, or ice can move or remove material as it flows.

913671FA3216460E8130E1FB835CD860.description: Changes to Earth's surface can be shared through scientific knowledge, stories and traditional knowledge

928719715DDB41DAA12E7B3855E6B5D4.description: Natural events that can change Earth's surface in a short period of time include volcanic eruptions, earthquakes, landslides, tsunamis, floods and melting and freezing

6179B47030814AF69D3F4DD14B61E986.description: Changes that can occur to Earth's surface over a long period of time include mountains wearing down, rivers changing course, lakes and seas drying out and refilling and glaciers moving, advancing, and receding

C2BD65D217F44927BD96059BA550EBCF.description: Students analyze changes in Earth's surface and explain how its layers hold stories of the past.

6EE50F54F5ED42A1B00254423132CAEC.description: Earth Systems: Understandings of the living world, Earth, and space are deepened by investigating natural systems and their interactions.

C29A607F39CB490D98FF74B2B0607015.description: Describe the purpose of simple machines used by local First Nations, Métis, and Inuit.

E7F9048C01414B61B80DA6DA36DEE6E4.description: Safely work with tools, materials, and equipment.

6627EA838B034BAA95929CEA9EB64208.description: Design a device that uses simple machines.

058F326C49CD4686A9A8852AF7C223D8.description: Explore how simple machines reduce the effort needed to move objects.

F174C72B3BC444B38BABFDD6684CB0D2.description: Conduct investigations to demonstrate how forces can change the shape or size of objects.

22B496101AA245B2BFDA87EE4B409EA8.description: Conduct investigations to demonstrate the effects of forces on the movement of objects.

9969ADED83D841D7A2596C3C27BA004C.description: Predict how an object will be affected by different strengths and directions of force.

0F82C7CBCB36493E91F8F5CED629C82C.description: Compare the strength of forces applied to objects.

B56032FAAABF41D1A513DAB1EF0E61E4.description: Describe the strength and direction of forces applied to objects.

F70851C627A9497F831C5710A33A5B25.description: Describe where forces may exist in everyday situations.

E570FDF64FEA4429BF96A0061A0E0BD7.description: Simple machines can change the strength and direction of forces.

37627B942A674F7C962C32D80F052097.description: Forces can affect properties and movement of objects in different ways.

18EBCFB1575C440AA25F1108EF0F5ED3.description: Many First Nations, Métis, and Inuit designed, tested, and continue to use simple machines, such as an antler wedge, a paddle and Inuit scraping tools; e.g., ulu

8C01A11965C24DFCB759CCAE14E37D45.description: The effort needed to move objects is reduced by simple machines, such as levers, wheels and inclined planes

6F53486F82784A7E8C83754F57D6564A.description: Changes to an object's movement when a force is applied include changing speed, starting, stopping and changing direction

5DE380F0C16348F5B17785B12C339E8A.description: The direction of forces applied to objects can be described a upward, downward, from the left, from the right, from both sides and from all directions

472A80F2CB924743A5D743136329A121.description: The strength of forces applied to objects can be described as strong, weak. large and small

7298582A651A49D490F63AA01E748747.description: Ways to apply a contact force to an object include stretching, pulling, squeezing and pushing

2ABC3A6C718F4010B82414A3137EEA67.description: Contact forces include forces that are applied by a person or an object on another object (applied), caused by objects, surfaces, or substances sliding against each other (friction), applied by pulling on a string or rope connected to an object (tension) and caused by a compressed or stretched object or spring (elastic or spring)

A32BB4FF88A2436AB90AEB0D3A22A515.description: Contact forces occur between objects that touch each other.

338AD5A54F184B5EBB0F806F6C740FCD.description: An object that is not moving will stay still until a force makes it move, and an object that is moving will keep moving until a force stops it. (Newton's First Law)

9DEC19A636504307A71B9119893E286C.description: A force is a push or pull on an object resulting from an interaction with another object.

C60D028F3B784B9F9EB7C9CAC273E420.description: Students investigate and explain how forces affect the movement of objects.

E94C033D55FB413EB785EA64C3AC0F9A.description: Energy: Understandings of the physical world are deepened by investigating matter and energy.

332D10225FCD4199BDB706E35BEF198D.description: Safely perform experiments on various materials and substances and classify changes as permanent or reversible.

1FA21AB77334413388DCF026EECD408F.description: Discuss examples of changes to materials or substances that are permanent and examples of changes to materials or substances that are reversible.

44AC2C45FDF2488CA09DC7B4858354F3.description: Discuss the importance of safety around bodies of water in different seasons.

A46079A7D5FD4BDEBB6E3F87098C376E.description: Discuss the importance of safety around bodies of water that have a surface of ice.

0E2DCBBE2A374987AE5191244A1B405F.description: Identify examples of changes in the state of water in local environments.

FE3C18BE477F447D91285A1973E1067E.description: Discuss ways to respect water in local environments.

489BC5DFCE584E31A0A5A19C7CFD12DE.description: Discuss examples of daily activities that include heating and cooling.

942978B04336489CAD6254AB96DD02C2.description: Conduct an investigation to demonstrate changes of state.

156B8BB0520E44D99082FBF7F3F442AF.description: Discuss how interaction with natural materials is guided by relationships with the land for First Nations, Métis, and Inuit communities.

A0D2083E2E5B4EDC9233D08DA2334B95.description: Relate a processed material to the natural material from which it originated.

FB8B40C3571146AD8CB8CD0DFF3D0F3B.description: Changes to materials or substances can be permanent or reversible, depending on the properties of the given materials or substances.

7355ACF80D794D38BA279465BA3934D0.description: The water on Earth moves continuously in a cycle.

ACDD4DF4CB7C4965AAB0921F05D46012.description: Substances change state based on melting/freezing and boiling points.

B5F2AB41649D4B9F9EFFA8B464BB8BED.description: Solids, liquids, and gases have distinct properties.

23E0BB5BF5E940688EB7BFF7A8AA3021.description: Matter can change state if heated or cooled.

B083341BA1F146B99334638F1A645D36.description: Interaction with natural materials by First Nations, Métis, and Inuit is guided through living in harmony and balance with the land.

B95AE46B79D649B0A85369BEF4039F3E.description: Materials can be used in their natural form or processed to create new materials.

79CFD8C923554E95AB55C8A0E9782033.description: A permanent change is a change that cannot be undone, such as cooking an egg or baking a cake.

1DEA7A6B214540BFA1E228E751E16883.description: A reversible change is a change that can be undone, such as melting or freezing.

87E5CA73081B4F9696822C55FB5A1EFE.description: In Alberta, the surfaces of many bodies of water change from liquid in the summer to solid in the winter.

CED5FDEFD4B64C2C87EC952950081B08.description: Water can change state from liquid to gas and back again.

3E6F263D98C94DBBA536DE4872402859.description: Water can change state from solid to liquid and back again.

8CB0D95D1BE5486C8D063BE237518953.description: In the water cycle, water changes state from a liquid to a gas through evaporation, forms clouds through condensation, then falls back to Earth in a liquid or solid state (precipitation).

F20C330641B048BB844ED04F0524226E.description: The water cycle is a process in which water on Earth moves continuously between bodies of water, land, and the atmosphere.

9CA69CE626C3495DA964A8047A5950D1.description: The boiling point of water is 100ºC.

DD57E5356EA949A68FF1D60CBFFF4F4B.description: The melting/freezing point of water is 0ºC.

55E7A11BC4D54E6C8412F671A4D6B3EF.description: The temperature at which a substance changes from liquid to gas is called the boiling point.

83619BB5BC2346919F5E58A4ADCAC8AD.description: The melting and freezing points of a substance are the same temperature.

3C5B4779AD634A5792D0533D752173F3.description: The temperature at which a substance changes from liquid to solid is called the freezing point.

2BD5ACCD909F4D5FB5CDA77DBB895FE5.description: The temperature at which a substance changes from solid to liquid is called the melting point.

8143EF055C7A43F28BE731F878682308.description: Substances are made of matter that has not been mixed with other matter, including water.

4CD13E80F3734080BD86EAB8A8B8B729.description: Volume is the amount of space a solid, liquid, or gas takes up.

2449362323074B83867D71B6CB2BCC28.description: A gas flows easily and expands to the size of the container it is in.

86DE6AFB3AD74C018A92FFD7B12636E3.description: A gas is a state of matter that has neither definite shape nor definite volume.

6E3E9D62ECD44EB99337462ED7B28528.description: A liquid flows and takes the shape of the container it is in.

5232AFD9C39F4AF49EFE51D113D50A78.description: A liquid is a state of matter that has a definite volume but no definite shape.

D016EC9FF1D34D598EF4A22BA883BEB3.description: A solid is a state of matter that has a definite shape and volume.

9D8096AA09AD4EDF92651C5D53A19309.description: Condensation is a change of state from gas to liquid.

B6877E5501AC498583148AD0FF15C6AB.description: Evaporation is a change of state from liquid to gas.

131CCA3D43DB40378C53F82AA95D1B6C.description: Freezing is a change of state from liquid to solid.

2E1B2A65ADAC4BCABC614B28B4CE5955.description: Melting is a change of state from solid to liquid.

8605E9426B704160833AF637E899CF1F.description: States of matter include solid, liquid, and gas.

EEF48191C579430DBFA60A4CE0E66879.description: Matter is anything that takes up space and has weight.

41AA21ECF7474FA9A9738C8399C57C28.description: First Nations, Métis, and Inuit communities interact with natural materials for specific purposes, such as teepees, igloos, medicines, clothing, transportation and ceremonies

8F064C8E50B94D97A4617985B0F1D093.description: First Nations, Métis, and Inuit communities respectfully interact with natural materials, such as trees, rocks, ice, shells, plants and animals

A8D9560D86DA4B2C908E9E438BBDABC6.description: Processed materials are designed and manufactured for a specific purpose.

D27C7AA4B3AA489684AD3B10F09E25FB.description: Processed materials are modified from natural materials and do not occur in nature.

EECCAFC9F91F4406B4D9412849BE226F.description: Students investigate and analyze how materials have the potential to be changed.

9651DAC0A53B4D7C9CA9A0CE156C3D3D.description: Matter: Understandings of the physical world are deepened by investigating matter and energy.
